scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains three bills of sale for enslaved persons sold to John Wesley Hunt of Lexington, Kentucky. Bill, an enslaved Black man about 19 years old, and Charles, an enslaved Black boy about 9 years old, both described as sound, healthy, and free of blemish, were sold by their enslaver, Minor Young, for $650 to be enslaved for life by John W. Hunt (July 19, 1806). Eliza, an enslaved Black girl about 15 years old and described as sound, healthy, sensible, and under good character, was sold by her enslaver, William Robinson, for $400 (September 1, 1806). Elijah, an enslaved Black boy about 10 years old who is described as sound and healthy, was sold by his enslaver, Thomas Hughes, for $270 to be enslaved for life by John W. Hunt (October 27, 1806).

Along with these bills of sale this folder contains a land grant, letters to John Wesley Hunt, account statements regarding John W. Hunt's purchases of goods from other businesses, and a bill of lading for goods shipped to Messers Hunt and Hankinson in St. Louis, Missouri. The land grant gave Isaac Clark 150 acres in Christian County, Kentucky, and was signed by Kentucky Governor Christopher Greenup. The letters to John W. Hunt relating to his trade business discuss sales of cordage, linen, and bagging, while letters regarding the horse business describe the lengthy process of purchasing a new horse, Dragon, from Wade Hampton.
